text: how did you do this do what this hi
everyone
Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest
music nerd time for review dr. John
locked down dr. John is a singer
songwriter multi-instrumentalist session
musician and iconic figure in New
Orleans music especially when it comes
to blues funk R&B jazz and psychedelic
rock there's been a lot of versatility
over the 20 or so albums this guy is
released over the years he's recently
been inducted into the Rock and Roll
Hall of Fame as well unfortunately his
music is not really garnering the net it
used to but this new help you locked
down is receiving some really positive
attention and for good reason it's a
solid album which we will get into later
but but part of the reason I think this
LP is catching some momentum momentum is
because it's a little change in
direction thanks to working with Dan
Auerbach of the Black Keys who produced
this LP and what Dan is doing for John
on this LP reminds me a lot of what Rick
Rubin was doing for Johnny Cash on his
final albums Rick revitalized Johnny's
sound not by going for something that
was that was really clean and sleek
slick and modern instead shooting for
something that's that's much more earthy
gritty the instrumentation on those
final cash records just sounded so aged
and weathered and Dan is basically doing
the same thing I don't think the good
doctor could have gotten a better
production endorsement from a modern
artist not only do I think Black Keys
fans can very easily slide into enjoying
this LP but the production Dan brings to
the table just like an usual Black Keys
fashion references the past which I
think old-school dr. John fans will
but it's got a really modern punch to it
the opener the title track to this album
starts with these birds squawking it's
like I'm in a bird sanctuary this drum
roll comes in building things up against
these kind of tribal chants and then
this clunky New Orleans style funk
groove comes in that not only references
old school dr. John but are just like
the meters and Lee Dorsey - and over
this funk groove to kind of back up the
hook that's really metallic vibraphone
and these backup vocals and and horns
come in kind of giving the track a
slightly lounge jazz feel I really love
the sounds the extra sounds that come
together on this track but the
foundational stuff the guitars the drums
the vocals they sound great - the drums
had to have a kind of I guess ratty
quality to them I want to see but not
ratty in a bad way they don't sound like
they're miked very close so you're
catching a lot of kit annoys a lot of
room noise but the drums still have a
lot of crispness to them and the guitars
which of course are played by Dan
Auerbach have that trademark black keys
tone to them the upright bass thuds away
basically the instrumentation to me
sounds like a beat-up old pickup truck
it's souped up the engine growls the
wheel wells are all rusted there's bugs
caught in the grille the windshield is
cracked but you know runs good and as
far as the vocals go I know this gets
set about a lot of aging the singers but
I'm not biessing here I do think dr.
John's voice has gotten more interesting
with old age it is so raspy rasp rasp
rasp his voice has always kind of had a
raspy quality to it but now it's just
more than ever and it's adding a lot of
character in a very Tom Waits kind of
way and dr. John still manages to carry
a tune be very emotive in these songs
and thanks to the lyrics on this
P he's sounding kind of fed up with the
world at large too
there are all sorts of words on on this
album referencing the present being an
ice age Liars going to hell people doing
drugs and losing their jobs revolution
is the final solution it's a bit of a
wake-up call because if you were to see
the world from dr. John's viewpoint it
would probably look like it's crumbling
fast vocally the only spots I'm not
really in love with on this album are
the moments where dr. John's vocal
melodies may be getting a little
repetitive on the verse or the verses
where he's not really so much singing as
he is doing a bit of a spoken word thing
I'm talking tracks like Ice Age big shot
you lie but the production the
songwriting and the instrumentation
whether it be similarly sultry horns or
a bright old-school organ oh that saves
these songs from being bad for sure I
understand these moments just aren't as
captivating to me I guess because this
album is solid enough to the point where
you could just ride through the lows and
it's not really a big deal because the
highs are so high there is a good amount
of variety on here - I like the brisk
speedy tempo on the track getaway which
is which isn't 3/4 and has a fantastic
guitar solo from Dan on the end of it I
love the slow brooding funk of kingdom
of isness the balladry that's happening
on my children my angels where the
lyrics tried to be a bit of advice to
the youth the next generation the track
a leg wah really pulls up the New
Orleans funk roots of this album like no
other track does lots of sharp guitar
leads very heavy very chunky drums and
the clothes are on here God sure go
takes a bit of a religious and a gospel
angle to this album finishing things off
on a kind of positive note overall it's
a very good album it's it's not exactly
new ground or mind-blowing for dr. John
but
it does sound great to hear and kind of
revitalized restored in a really
tasteful way so definitely check this
thing out it's the kind of stuff that
that swamps and and hard liquor and
dusty old bars and and the sweat beating
off the head of a lone saxophone player
at some smoky nightclub where the
maximum capacity is 50 people is made of
definitely feeling a strong 7 on this
thing what did you guys think of it did
you love it
did you hate it why and what should I
review next anthony Fantana dr. John
forever
